ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I developed knowledge of how to read the music system Professor Quinn created. I could sightread that pretty well.

This class was a complete waste of time. I came into the class hoping to learn music theory (as one does when they sign up for a music theory class) and I can confidently say that I did not learn a single thing. Professor Quinn developed his own music notation and therefore we only touched upon Western music notation in the last week of class, which was useless because we had essentially not learned a single thing for the entire semester prior to this. I really regret taking this class and had wished I signed up for literally anything else -- I feel like I wasted a credit taking this class.
Learning basics of music theory and how to read music
Music
I am honestly not entirely sure what I learned from this class... The most useful skill I learned was how to transcribe music into standard western music notation.

Really brilliant fundamental musicianship -- not just what notes are where, but why. Do re mi fa so la ti do is just the start of it -- the skills you learn in this class about the history and backdrop to so much of modernday music is invaluable.
Not only did I gain a greater understanding of the fundamental elements of music theory, but I also learned about the vastness of music and the different lenses from which music can be viewed.
Learned about solfege and intervals.
I dont feel as though my sight reading ability has improved much at all.

I learned a lot more about the technical aspects of music while taking this class. I do not have a major musical background so it was very interesting to learn about the different scales and forms of music.
A great understanding of the fundamentals of music and how to transcribe and read notation.
I strengthened my music theory basis and learned more through studying non-Western musical traditions.

Through this class, I learned many basics of music theory from intervals to time signatures. My favorite aspect of the class was that all of these components were taught through singing solfege, something that was very new to me.
I learned some of the fundamental aspects of music (like time and pitch), how it is notated, and how that notation originated.
I learned a lot about solfege and musical counting.

I really internalized how music is a full-body experience. There is so much more to listening to music than just hearing itthe sensations within your body also contribute to staying in time, understanding intent, and enjoying the experience.
I learned about solfge and different types of scales, as well as the circle of fifths.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I really enjoyed the beginning of the course, and how it was structured as a "singing school." I thought that was fun, and I felt like I was gradually learning more about rhythm and sight-reading. I liked how we weren't focusing on Western standard notation, because I'd never seen that before. The system Professor Quinn created was also interesting. We weren't learning traditional music theory, but based on what the instructors were telling me, I believed it would all come together at the end of the course, and we would learn standard music notation. However, it never really came together. I felt like we spent the majority of the time sight-singing, and only really touched standard music notation during the last 4-ish classes. It felt like a total 180 from what we had been doing, and I found it really hard to keep up with the music jargon. I felt I came into this course wanting to learn standard music notation, and just be able to understand more about music, and I don't think this class helped me fully achieve that. I also felt that even though this class is meant for those with little to no experience with music, many people in the class actually had a lot of experience, which made discussion sections hard to follow, since people were using advanced terms I had not heard before. Overall, I think this course could be improved by having more emphasis on music notation and integrating standard music notation more with the system Professor Quinn created.

The only strength I can think of is that there was almost no homework. As for weaknesses, the entire class was a disappointment. I really wanted to learn music theory and I wish I took literally any class besides this one. I don't understand what Professor Quinn was trying to do this semester but it really just wasted all of our time.
It could have been a little better organized from the start. The syllabus was constructed on the fly and semester was a bit experimental, so there were a few hiccups organizationally.
Not well organised
A weakness of this class is that it didn't know what it wanted to be this semester and was taking a new approachsometimes it paid off and somtimes it didn't.

Strengths: super fun, not boring, easy homework, intuitive, GREAT TA's, fun final project! 

weaknesses: sometimes poorly run, the professor would neglect to show up occasionally and left us with a less-than-satisfying curriculum to follow. I also think we spent too much time on South Asian/Indian roots and chords, because the point of the course was to work us up to the Western Staff and we barely spent time on that by the end of the semester

(It should be noted, though, that my class was the first 110 class to exist like this, so we were guinea pigs.)

Strengths: low workload, fun, engaging final project. Weaknesses: disorganized, assignments are posted 1-2 days before they are due, skills aren't that transferrable to instruments but very applicable to voice/singing., didn't learn everything that was in the course description.
Too simple. I could have taken this class in fifth grade.

Strength  very engaging. 
Weakness  says that it is for non-music major but I found that many of the topics discussed in group sections were themes that we did not discuss in class. I was confused frequently.
A more set structure would be appreciated, but the style is unique and works.

In class, the course is very engaging and requires your full attention, which I enjoyed. However, because it was the first time the class was being taught in this way, some parts of it felt a bit disorganized.

I loved that this class addresses the basics of music theory from a non-"western" centric perspective. We spent several weeks several weeks singing in the Southern Carnatic Indian scale system, and had two guest presenters discussing Canadian Indigenous music and dancing. I loved how engaged each lecture was with singing exercises for at least half of the block. My only suggestion would be to add in more instruction on transcription techniques and technology such as Musescore earlier in the course. From seeing next semester's syllabus, it sounds like this suggestion has already been implemented.

I love the singing school aspect of this course. This was the very first year this course was taught, so it was understandably very disorganized and experimental. The syllabus for next semester looks much more organized and in-depth.

Strengths: I like that the instructor included a lot of non-Western music notation. I learned a few more terms than I had known in the past, and I feel excited to learn more about music theory in the future.

Weaknesses: perhaps more of a syllabus would have been helpful just in choosing which courses to enroll in, but I honestly did not mind the quizzes being somewhat-randomly added throughout the semester. They were manageable, but perhaps could have been difficult if the workload was a LOT.

I really enjoyed the singing school format, and think singing as a group is a great way to learn. I also really liked my section and found that to be quite helpful. 

As for how the class could be improved, I feel that too much time was spent on the singing exercises and not enough on introducing notation. If the dept wanted to get away from just western notation, why not teach other traditions of music by themselves? 

While its evident Dr. Quinns made up notation was very thoughtful and took a lot of work, I dont know that it helped us understand western notation any better. I wouldve enjoyed a course that introduced a few different notations and then spent more time on western notation. I dont feel prepared for upcoming music classes.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Based on how the course was this semester, no. However, I understand that this was the first time this class had been taught, so the instructors were also figuring it out as they went along. We received a syllabus for the next semester on the last day of class, and based on that, it seems like the class will be much more effective at teaching music theory next semester. So I think it depends, because MUSI 110 next semester will be different from the MUSI 110 I experienced.

Please don't take this class, take literally any other class. Probably don't take a class with Professor Quinn in case he tries to teach his own notation again... Just have some respect for your own time and don't take this class.
Yes, but keep in mind that the syllabus is changing drastically for future semesters. The syllabus is probably more valuable than the reviews for this semester given how much will be changing
Not really
If you like to sing during class and generally like music, I would recommend this class. If you are looking for deep technical knowledge I would not recommend this class.

Absolutely. If you're anything like me and play instruments/love music but don't know how to read notes, this is the class for you. I'm not 100% there yet, but I wouldn't even have the guts to try reading staff if I hadn't taken this course. It's so cool to be in a big lecture with people from all different musical backgrounds, interested in gaining a fundamental understanding of something that means so much to all of us.
Yes! As someone who grew up viewing music through the western classical perspective, I found this course super enlightening and very interesting.

If you want to take a fun and unique class, then yes I would recommend it. If you are looking to gain a better foundation in music theory because you play an instrument (other than voice), then no I do not recommend.
Unless there was a large overhaul of the material then I would not recommend
Yes! I thought it was a very interesting class. Anyone who is interested in music should take this course!
Yes! This is a great intro music course and would recommend to anyone interested in the subject
Yes

I would definitely recommend this course to another student (and already have). I loved the focus on non-Western musical traditions as a way to teach music theory, and I felt more engaged in this class than I have in any other music theory class before.

I would definitely recommend this course to any student wanting to not only build a stronger base in music theory, but also look at the relationship of intervals through sight singing. As an instrumentalist, this was new for me and I found it to be very rewarding not only in building a new skill, but also deepening my understanding of intervals.
I would recommend this course. The act of gathering and singing together is truly magical, and with the new structure next semester, this course will be excellent.

Absolutely. If you're not interested in Music as a major or anything, this course is still designed to bring an understanding to music that goes beyond simply hearing it. You start to notice different elements of music composition even when simply listening to pop music, and the insights are genuinely exciting. Highly recommend. The workload is not overbearing at all, and will certainly fit in with other courses.

With no change to the current curriculum, I wouldnt recommend the course as I feel I didnt learn much. Ive had some musical experience, which is completely what I relied on to complete the homework and the final project. The notation Dr. Quinn made up was very confusing and I dont think it would make sense to people who havent seen much notation before.
